title: Disclosure of the name of a program that has a private part with an external link

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
Hi team , @jobert , @bencode . Not so long ago, you made an output to the program panel of information about whether the program has the function- `retest`. Also, this is reflected in the report by the attribute `active_retest_subscription`. It seems that it is reflected in publish reports that are created in programs that have external links. The function itself cannot be enabled in the sandbox, which means that it can only be found in real programs. It turns out that if we see this attribute in the report, it means that the program is real, which means it is private

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Go to https://hackerone.com/hacktivity/publish
2. Input program , create reports
3. Check .json report - https://hackerone.com/reports/ID.json

If we see this attribute, it means that the program is private. And it has the `retest` function enabled

Thanks!
@haxta4ok00

## Impact

Disclosure of the name of a program that has a private part with an external link

Also, this is reflected in the report by the attribute active_retest_subscription. It seems that it is reflected in publish reports that are created in programs that have external links. It turns out that if we see this attribute in the report, it means that the program is real, which means it is private

activities.message:
Hi @haxta4ok00,

Thank you for your submission. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Kind regards,
@turtle_shell

activities.message: Hi @haxta4ok00 - thanks for this! I've escalated this to the team working on this particular feature. We'll keep you posted!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @haxta4ok00 - thanks for this! I've escalated this to the team working on this particular feature. We'll keep you posted!

activities.message: Hi @jobert -- Thank you for the bounty!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @jobert -- Thank you for the bounty!

activities.message:
Hello, Hackerone, thank you for the opportunity to retest this report.
To retest this vulnerability I published report in one program which have external link and at the same time have private program to check for `active_retest_subscription` attribute in the json file which would prove that private program exists and I haven't found it. Also I checked for the same attribute in private programs which have private disclosures enabled and in the public programs and the attribute `active_retest_subscription` is missing. 
I believe that this vulnerability is fixed.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello, Hackerone, thank you for the opportunity to retest this report.
To retest this vulnerability I published report in one program which have external link and at the same time have private program to check for active_retest_subscription attribute in the json file which would prove that private program exists and I haven't found it. Also I checked for the same attribute in private programs which have private disclosures enabled and in the public programs and the attribute active_retest_subscription is missing.
I believe that this vulnerability is fixed.

activities.message:
Hi @say_ch33se -- Thank you for checking my report for fixed! I just wanted to clarify to you that you needed to check a program that has the retest function enabled. To do this, the program has a label on the main page of any program - `Includes retesting` 

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @say_ch33se -- Thank you for checking my report for fixed! I just wanted to clarify to you that you needed to check a program that has the retest function enabled. To do this, the program has a label on the main page of any program - Includes retesting

Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi, @haxta4ok00, thanks for the clarification. I did check for that attribute on the program which has that label, which in my case is ford program and hackerone program and I can't confirm that it doesn't disclose the presence of the private program because I'm not part of such programs and can't know for sure whether they exist or not. If I were in a private program that have that option enabled I could compare and confirm whether that attribute confirms the existence of the private program.
I hope I understood this vulnerability right and that I didn't overthink it

activities.message:
Hi @say_ch33se , If you meant ███ , this is a public program. 

>I hope I understood this vulnerability right and that I didn't overthink it

It's ok , This vulnerability requires an external program, example : ██████ , █████, ███, ... etc.

activities.message:
If I understood it right, I should find an external program which has a label `Includes retesting` than after submitting a report the json file of the report should contain `active_retest_subscription` attribute which would prove the existence of the private program? The problem here is that I can't find not one external program which has `Includes retesting` label.
I'm sorry if I'm taking too much of your time, I want to do this right but I'm struggling to understand the approach
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hey @say_ch33se , Don't worry, you did everything right, you just was had a little less information.

>If I understood it right, I should find an external program which has a label Includes retesting than after submitting a report the json file of the report should contain active_retest_subscription attribute which would prove the existence of the private program

Yes, This was before the fix . The fix is that this attribute should no longer be disclosed in a report sent to an external program via /publish

> I'm sorry if I'm taking too much of your time, I want to do this right but I'm struggling to understand the approach

Don't worry, it's all right, any questions!

I'm sorry if I'm taking too much of your time, I want to do this right but I'm struggling to understand the approach

Don't worry, it's all right, any questions!
